data.event: It was the first colony in Delaware, founded by the Dutch in 1631, and it remained the only significant European settlement in the region for some time.

event.title: organized the three southern counties of Pennsylvania, which are now

data.event: When English colonists William Penn organized the three southern counties of Pennsylvania, which are now Delaware, Lewes was the natural choice for the location of the Sussex County's Seat of Justice.

event.title: was not well defined until after 1760

data.event: Sussex County was not well defined until after 1760, following resolution of a dispute between William Penn's family and Frederick Calvert, 6th Baron Baltimore after intervention from the Crown.

event.title: continued into Fenwick Island, which it now

data.event: Earlier Charles Calvert, 5th Baron Baltimore had argued that the county ended with Lewes, while Penn's sons stated it continued into Fenwick Island, which it now does.
